questions.text: Principal cells and intercalated cells are present in which part of the nephron?

choices.text: Distal collecting tubule and collecting duct
Proximal collecting tubule and loop of Henle
Loop of Henle and distal collecting tubule

questions.solution:
Principal cells and intercalated cells are present in the distal collecting tubule and collecting duct. 

  P cell I cell
Functions
  • Na+reabsorption
  • Water reabsorption
  • K secretion
  • Type A- H+ secretion, HCO3 reabsorption in acidosis.
  • Type B- HCO3 secretion,  acid reabsorption in alkalosis.

Note: Principal cells are the primary sites of action of potassium-sparing diuretics.

questions.text: How does DCT differ from PCT?

choices.text: Carbonic anhydrase in its luminal membrane
No Na+ - K+ ATPase in its basolateral membrane

questions.solution:
DCT has 'tight' tight junctions, while PCT has 'leaky' tight junctions.

The 'tight' tight junctions can maintain the high electrochemical gradients produced by active transcellular transport. This configuration is used to produce either highly concentrated or diluted secretions, as in the distal nephron. Hence, it can produce urine with osmolarity severalfold higher or lower than plasma.

In contrast, epithelia with 'leaky' tight junctions move large amounts of isosmotic fluids. A good example is a transport in PCT.

PCT

DCT

Brush border present in the apical membrane

No brush border

Cytoplasmic carbonic anhydrase (type 2 & type 4) present

Cytoplasmic carbonic anhydrase (type 2 only)

Has ‘leaky’ tight junctions

Has ‘tight’ tight junctions

Paracellular transport is possible via leaky tight junctions

No paracellular transport

Na+- K- ATPase is present throughout most parts of the nephron.

questions.text: In comparison to cortical nephron, juxtamedullary nephron______
questions.solution:
In comparison to cortical nephrons, juxtamedullary nephrons are characterized by a long loop of Henle that descends deep into the inner medulla. It is essential for the concentration of urine.

Related Pearl: Differences between cortical and juxtamedullary nephron

questions.text: About what percentage of the cardiac output do the kidneys receive?
questions.solution:
Kidneys receive approximately 20 to 25% of the cardiac output, which is approximately 1000 mL per minute.

Region Blood flow (ml/min)

Liver

 

 1500

Kidneys

 

 1260

Brain

 

 750

Skeletal muscle

 

 840

Heart muscles

 

 250

questions.text: What is the normal resting GFR?
questions.solution:
The GFR in a healthy adult of average size is approximately 125 mL/min.

Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is the volume of fluid filtered from the renal glomerular capillaries into the Bowman's capsule per unit time.

The GFR is determined by

  1. Sum of the hydrostatic and colloid osmotic forces across the glomerular membrane, which gives the net filtration pressure
  2. Glomerular Kf (glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient)

Mathematically, it can be expressed as follows:

GFR= Kf [ forces favoring filtration- forces opposing filteration]

GFR= Kf [PG + πB -PB- πG]

Forces Favoring Filtration

PG: Glomerular hydrostatic pressure 

πB: Bowman’s capsule oncotic pressure 

Forces Opposing Filtration 

PB: Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure 

πG: Glomerular capillary oncotic pressure

questions.text: What is the renal blood flow in a resting adult?
questions.solution:
In a resting adult, the kidneys receive 1.2–1.3 L of blood per minute or just under 25% of the cardiac output. Among the given options, 1-1.5 L/min is the closest range. 

Renal blood flow is determined by the pressure gradient across the renal vasculature (the difference between the renal artery and renal vein hydrostatic pressures), divided by the total renal vascular resistance. It is expressed as follows:

Note: Renal blood flow = Renal plasma flow/ 1- Hematocrit

questions.text: What is the normal renal filtration fraction?
questions.solution:
Normal renal filtration fraction (i.e. the fraction of renal plasma flow that is filtered) averages about 0.2.

It means that 20% of the plasma flowing through the kidney is filtered through the glomerular capillaries. The remaining 80% leaves the glomerular capillaries by the efferent arterioles and becomes the peritubular capillary circulation.

It is calculated by the given equation:

When there is a fall in systemic blood pressure, the GFR falls less than the RPF because of efferent arteriolar constriction, and consequently, the filtration fraction rises.

questions.text: Which of the following does not form filtration barrier?
questions.solution:
Mesangium does not form a filtration barrier. It is made up of mesangial cells, supporting glomerular capillaries. 

The filtration barrier consists of:

  • Endothelium of the capillary
  • Basement membrane:
    • Lamina densa - electron-dense layer. It contains type IV collagen
    • Lamina rara interna - contains glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate which has a negative charge
    • Lamina rara externa - contains glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate which has a negative charge
  • Layer of epithelial cells (podocytes) surrounding the outer surface of the capillary basement membrane

A. The endothelial cells of the glomerulus; 1. Pore (fenestra)

B. Glomerular basement membrane: 1. Lamina rara interna 2. Lamina densa 3. Lamina rara externa

C. Podocytes: 1. Enzymatic and structural protein 2. Filtration slit 3. Diaphragm.

questions.text: Two particles share the same diameter. The one which will pass through the glomerular membrane has ______

choices.text: Filtration across GBM does not depend on charge

questions.solution:
For any given molecular radius, positively charged molecules are filtered much more readily than are negatively charged molecules.

This is because the sialoproteins in the glomerular capillary wall are negatively charged, and this negative charge repels the negatively charged substances in the blood.

Studies have showed that for tracer molecules presumed to be of similar size, charges which are filtered are positive charge > neutral charge > negative charge.

questions.text: What size of neutral substances are permitted by the filtration barriers?
questions.solution:
Filtration barriers permit neutral substances that have the size of 4-8 nm.

Neutral substances with diameters:

  • <4 nm - freely filtered
  • >8 nm - not filtered
  • Between 4-8 nm - the permeability is inversely proportional to the diameter

Clinical correlation:

  • Genetically abnormal basement membranes: Alport’s syndrome (α3 and α4 chains on the long arm of chromosome 2 involved in autosomal dominant and recessive pattern; α5 chain on X chromosome involved in X-linked inheritance)
  • Autoimmune response to basement membrane collagen IV (α3 NC1 domain): Goodpasture’s syndrome

Related Pearl: Inherited causes of nephrotic syndrome

Gene involved

Protein

  Disease Phenotype Inheritance Pattern

NPHS1  (Ch.19q)

Nephrin

Congenital Nephrotic syndrome (Finnish Type) 

Autosomal recessive

NPHS2  (Ch.1q)

Podocin

 Steroid resistant nephrotic syndrome Autosomal recessive 

TRPC6

Transient receptor potential cation channel 6

 Adult onset FSGS Autosomal dominant 

ACTN4

Alpha-actinin 4

 FSGS Autosomal dominant  

FSGS: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

NOTE: Inherited forms of nephrotic syndrome are invariably resistant to immunosuppressants (steroid resistant)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus?
questions.solution:
Glomerular mesangial cells are not a part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus. 

Juxtaglomerular apparatus contains:

  • Macula densa: Specialized cells at the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle forms the macula densa. They detect sodium concentration of the fluid in the tubule (Chemoreceptor). In response to elevated sodium, the macula densa cells trigger contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. 
  • Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole.
  • Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, that secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure.

Note: The distal convoluted tubule starts at the macula densa.

questions.text: In patients with renal diseases, albumin is the first to appear in the urine. What is the reason behind this?
questions.solution:
In renal diseases, albumin is the first to appear because of its effective molecular diameter. 

In minimal change nephropathy, the negative charges on the basement membrane are lost even before there are noticeable changes in kidney histology. As a result of this loss of negative charges on the basement membranes, some of the lower molecular weight proteins, especially albumin (effective molecular diameter of 7 nm), are filtered and appear in the urine, a condition known as proteinuria or albuminuria.

questions.text:
Calculate the net filtration pressure across the GBM for a patient with 
Glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient = 6
Glomerular hydrostatic pressure  =45
Glomerular capillary oncotic pressure =20
Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure  =10
Bowman’s capsule oncotic pressure  =0
questions.solution:
Net filtration pressure = Hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries - Pressure in Bowman's capsule - Oncotic pressure in the glomerular capillaries.

Net filtration pressure= [PG -PB- πG+ πB]

Therefore,

Net filtration pressure      = (45-10-20+0)

                                         = 25-10  

                                         = 15 mmHg

Note: 

Here, just the net filtration pressure is asked and not the GFR.

GFR= Kf [PG -PB- πG+ πB]

questions.text: How much is the inulin clearance?
questions.solution:
Inulin clearance is equal to 125 ml/ min. Since it is used for the measurement of GFR, inulin clearance will be equal to GFR, i.e 125 ml/min

Renal clearance is the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per unit time. 

A higher renal clearance suggests the substance may be cleared almost completely in one pass through the kidneys while a low value describes a substance that may not be eliminated by the kidneys at all.

Clearance refers to the volume of plasma that would be necessary to supply the amount of substance excreted in the urine per unit of time. Stated mathematically,

Cx. Px = Ux. V

where Cx is the clearance rate of a substance x

Px is the plasma concentration of x

Ux is the urine concentration of that x

V is the urine flow rate

Rearranging this equation, clearance can be expressed as

questions.text: In a patient, urine flow rate is 10 mL/min; plasma inulin is 2 mg/mL; and urine inulin is 25 mg/mL. Which of the following is true assuming GFR to be normal?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, inulin clearance = GFR.

Inulin clearance is calculated by the formula:

Substituting the values given,

  • Uinulin= 25 mg/mL
  • Vinulin= 10 mL/min
  • Pinulin=2 mg/mL

Thus, Inulin clearance=GFR (normal GFR= 125 ml/min)

Inulin is a polymer of fructose, clearance of inulin can be used for measurement of GFR, because of the following reasons: 

  • Freely filtered
  • Neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubules
  • Nontoxic
  • Not metabolized by the body

questions.text: A patient's urine flow rate is 2 ml/min. What is the clearance of a substance x whose plasma concentration is 10mg/mL and in urine is 100mg/mL?
questions.solution:
The clearance in the given scenario is 20 ml/ min.

C = Clearance (mL/min)

[U]x = Urine concentration of substance x (mg/mL)=100mg/mL

V= Urine flow rate per minute (mL/min)=2mL/min

[P]x = Plasma concentration of substance x (mg/mL)=10mg/mL

Substituting the values,

questions.text: What is the effect of sympathetic stimulation on GFR?
questions.solution:
GFR decreases with sympathetic stimulation as there is afferent arteriolar constriction.

Strong activation of the renal sympathetic nerves constrict the afferent and efferent renal arterioles through the α1 receptors. As the afferent areterioles have far more α1 receptors than the efferent, it results in decreased renal blood flow and GFR.

questions.text: If a patient is on a high protein diet, what will be the effect on the GFR?
questions.solution:
High protein intake increases GFR. 

Note: Increase in the plasma protein concentration is not the same as high protein intake. An increase in the plasma protein concentration decreases GFR due to a raised oncotic pressure. A high protein intake raises the amino acid concentration in the blood, not the plasma protein concentration.

questions.text: Which of the following would cause an increase in both GFR and RPF?
questions.solution:
Dilation of the afferent arteriole will increase both GFR and RPF.

  • Increase renal plasma flow (RPF) - because renal vascular resistance is decreased
  • Increase glomerular filtration rate (GFR) - because glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure is increased.
  • Filtration fraction (FF) remains normal 

Dilation of the efferent arteriole will increase RPF but decrease GFR.

questions.text: Which of the following causes relaxation of the mesangial cells?
questions.solution:
cAMP causes relaxation of the mesangial cells. The other agents mentioned in the options cause contraction of the mesangial cells.

Agents causing relaxation of mesangial cells (mnemonic - DAnCE)

  • Dopamine
  • ANP
  • cAMP
  • PGE2

Angiotensin II is an important regulator of mesangial contraction, and there are angiotensin II receptors in the glomeruli.

Related Pearl: Agents causing contraction or relaxation of mesangial cells

Contraction of mesangial cells:

  • Endothelins
  • Angiotensin II
  • Vasopressin
  • Norepinephrine
  • Platelet-activating factor
  • Platelet-derived growth factor
  • Thromboxane A2
  • PGF2
  • Leukotrienes C4 and D4
  • Histamine

Relaxation of mesangial cells:

  • ANP
  • Dopamine
  • PGE2
  • cAMP

questions.text: What is the effect of prostaglandins on renal blood flow?

choices.text: Increase blood flow to cortex and medulla
Increase blood flow to cortex and decrease blood flow to medulla
Decrease blood flow to cortex and increase blood flow to medulla
Decrease blood flow to cortex as well as medulla

questions.solution:
Prostaglandins increase blood flow in the renal cortex and decrease blood flow in the renal medulla. 

PGE2 is partially responsible for the vasodilatation of the afferent arteriole, which increases blood flow to the glomerulus. This phenomenon describes why NSAIDs (which inhibit prostaglandin synthesis) result in afferent arteriole vasoconstriction. It can cause a reduced GFR in patients who rely heavily on prostaglandin synthesis to maintain renal blood flow.

questions.text: Which part of the proximal tubule is most susceptible to ischemic injury?
questions.solution:
Regions of the kidney most prone to ischemic injury are the S3 segment of the proximal tubule and the medullary thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (mTAL). These tubular areas exist physiologically in relatively lower oxygen conditions.

The S3 segment, in particular, has a much lower capability of producing energy through glycolysis under anaerobic conditions than the mTAL.

Based on the ultrastructure proximal tubule is divided into three segments:

  • S1 segment: 1st half of PCT
  • S2 segment: 2nd half of PCT and 1st half of proximal straight tubule
  • S3 segment: 2nd half of proximal straight tubule

questions.text: What is the effective renal plasma flow?
questions.solution:
In humans, the effective renal plasma flow (eRPF) averages about 625 mL/min.

Measurement of renal plasma flow (RPF) is done by measuring the clearance of para-aminohippuric acid (PAH). PAH is filtered and secreted by the renal tubules, hence it it can be used for RPF measurement.

where:

  • RPF = renal plasma flow (mL/min or mL/24 hour)
  • CPAH = clearance of PAH (mL/min or mL/24 hourr)
  • UPAH = urine concentration of PAH (mg/mL)
  • V = urine flow rate (mL/min or mL/24 hour)
  • PPAH = plasma concentration of PAH (mg/mL)

Note: Renal blood flow= Renal plasma flow/ 1- Hematocrit

questions.text: Which of the following formulae is correct?
questions.solution:
True renal plasma flow (RPF) is obtained by dividing effective renal plasma flow (ERPF) by extraction ratio.

When we inject para-aminohippuric acid, 90% of it is filtered through the glomerulus at the rate of 625mL per minute - which is the effective renal plasma flow (ERPF). Using that, to we calculate the true RPF,  we divide it by the extraction ratio to account for the 10% that is not filtered by dividing the ERPF by 0.9, hence getting the final value of ~ 700mL per minute

When peripheral venous plasma concentration of PAH is used for calculation of RPF, RPF obtained is called effective renal plasma flow (ERPF). This is because PAH concentration is essentially identical to that in the arterial plasma reaching the kidney.

questions.text: In a patient with renal disease, you want to measure the filtration fraction. Which of the following substances will you use?
questions.solution:
Inulin and PAHA are used to determine the filtration fraction. The filtration fraction is the ratio of GFR and RPF 

Inulin, a polymer of fructose can be used to measure GFR. Para-aminohippuric acid (PAHA) is used to measure RPF.

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by______
questions.solution:
The afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch induced by the opening of calcium channels. The mechanism is called myogenic autoregulation of renal blood flow and GFR. 

The stretch of the vascular wall allows increased movement of calcium ions from the extracellular fluid into the cells, causing them to contract. This contraction prevents excessive stretch of the vessel. This prevents excessive increase of renal blood flow and GFR by raising vascular resistance.

This mechanism may be more important in protecting the kidney from hypertension-induced injury.

Autoregulation has two main mechanisms:

  • Metabolic mechanism: Tissues produce vasodilatory metabolites that regulate flow e.g. prostaglandins, NO, CO2, H+ and K+
  • Myogenic mechanism

questions.text: Tubuloglomerular feedback is mediated by the sensing of_____

choices.text: Increased Na + concentration in thick ascending loop of Henle
Increased Cl - concentration in thick ascending loop of Henle
Increased Na + concentration in macula densa
Increased Cl- concentration in macula densa

questions.solution:
Tubuloglomerular feedback is mediated by the sensing of increased Na+ concentration in macula densa.

Macula densa are the specialized cells present at the distal end of the thick ascending loop of Henle where it reaches the glomerulus. Distal convoluted tubule starts from macula densa. Macula forms part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus.

While both Na+ and Cl- are delivered to the macula densa cells, it is the increased concentration of Na+ in the cells that increases the Na+-K ATPase activity leading to the feedback.

questions.text: Renal autoregulation is absent in which of the following cases?
questions.solution:
Renal autoregulation is absent in case of paralysis of vascular smooth muscle. 

Paralysis of vascular smooth muscles abolishes its action i.e., autoregulation of renal blood flow and GFR. Vascular smooth muscles act through myogenic mechanism of renal autoregulation. Paralysis of vascular smooth muscles can be brought about by administration of drugs.

Renal autoregulation is present in denervated and in iso­lated, perfused kidneys.

Feedback mechanisms intrinsic to the kidneys keep the renal blood flow and GFR relatively constant, despite marked changes in arterial blood pressure. This relative constancy of GFR and renal blood flow is referred to as autoregulation.

questions.text: Kidney responds to shock by _______.
questions.solution:
Kidney responds to shock by increasing afferent arteriolar resistance.

During shock, both afferent and efferent arterioles in kidney are constricted, however, the efferent vessels are constricted much more.
The glomerular filtration rate and the plasma renal flow is decreased during shock. As plasma renal flow is decreased to a greater extent, the filtration fraction increases. (Option 1 & 3)

questions.text: What is the function of tubuloglomerular feedback?
questions.solution:
Tubuloglomerular feedback regulates glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

As the rate of ﬂow through the ascending limb of the loop of Henle and first part of the distal tubule increases, glomerular filtration in the same nephron decreases, and, conversely, a decrease in ﬂow increases the GFR.

questions.text: The concentration of a substance is 2 mg % in afferent arteriole and 0 mg% in the efferent arteriole of a patient. This substance is
questions.solution:
A concentration of 0 mg% is efferent arteriole indicates the substance is freely filtered.

Afferent arterioles → glomerulus (filtration) → efferent arterioles → peritubular capillaries (reabsorption+secretion).

Note: The question compares the concentration in afferent and efferent arterioles. Reabsorption and secretion happen between the tubular lumen of the nephron and the peritubular capillaries and not the efferent arteriole.

questions.text: The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is?
questions.solution:
The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is heparan sulfate. It prevents filtration by repelling negatively charged proteins.

Collagen type IV, fibronectin, entactin are structural components of basement membrane.

Related Pearl: Biologically important Glycosoaminoglycans(GAG's)

GAG

Keratan sulfate

questions.text: Efferent arteriolar constriction causes all except:

choices.text: Decreases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries
Increases hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries

questions.solution:
Efferent arteriolar constriction increases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries.

Efferent arteriolar constriction has a biphasic response on GFR depending on the severity of resistance.

Moderate efferent arteriolar constriction causes increased glomerular hydrostatic pressure and slightly increased GFR. 

However, in cases of severe efferent arteriolar constriction (more than threefold increase in efferent arteriolar resistance), the renal blood flow is significantly reduced. This results in increased plasma protein concentration, thereby increasing the glomerular colloid oncotic pressure. As the increase in colloid oncotic pressure exceeds the increase in hydrostatic pressure, the net force for filtration decreases, resulting in decreased GFR.

questions.text: GFR is increased by all except
questions.solution:
Ureteric stone causes a reduction in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

Following ureteral obstruction, there is a progressive fall in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) due to a reduction in a single-nephron glomerular filtration rate (SNGFR) and a reduced number of filtering nephrons.

All the other factors/options increase GFR.

questions.text: This is the graph depicting the filterability of dextran through the kidney, 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Choose the substance A, B, C respectively.
questions.solution:
In the given graph, the order of filterability is A>B>C, which likely indicates that the substances are Polycationic, Neutral, Polyanionic.

The glomerular filtration barrier is negatively charged, which will repel most of the negative charged (anionic substances). Whereas, the cationic substances are easily filtered.

Hence, the order of filterability would be: Polycationic > Neutral > Polyanionic, represented by A, B, and C in the graph shown.

The glomerular filtration barrier consists of:

  • Endothelium of the capillary
  • Basement membrane: 
    • Lamina densa - electron-dense layer. It contains type IV collagen
    • Lamina rara interna - contains glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate which has a negative charge
    • Lamina rara externa - contains glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate which has a negative charge
  • Layer of epithelial cells (podocytes) surrounding the outer surface of the capillary basement membrane

The capillary endothelium is perforated by thousands of small holes called fenestrae, which measure from 4 nm up to 8nm. Therefore, neutral substances with molecular diameters of less than 4 nm are freely filtered, and filtration of those with diameters of more than 8 nm approaches zero.

However, in addition to the size of the particles, the filtration also depends mainly on the charge of the particle being filtered. The glomerular capillary wall consists of highly negatively charged proteins called sialoproteins, which repel the negatively charged substances (anions). The property can be studied by using charged dextran.

When the filtration of the negatively and positively charged dextrans was studied, the results indicated that the negatively charged dextrans in the blood are repelled, with the result that filtration of anionic substances 4 nm in diameter is less than half that of neutral substances of the same size.

This explains, why albumin despite having an effective molecular diameter of approximately 7 nm, has a very low filtration rate.
